definition[0]: in Britain, the standard rate of interest1(4), set by the Bank of England, on which all British banks base their charges
definition[1]: the basic rate of interest charged by the BANK OF ENGLAND, that replaced the BANK RATE and the MINIMUM LENDING RATE. The rates charged by all banks on their lending rise and fall with the base rate, and this has an important influence on the economy as a whole. Bank rate and minimum lending rate are still used in Britain and other countries to talk about the base rate
example[0]: You will pay 2% below the base rate for the first two years of your mortgage.
